We compare numbers to get a sense of how big one is versus the other. For example, let's say the teacher gave 5 chocolates to you and 3 chocolates to your friend. Who has more chocolates? You do! This is because 5 is greater than 3. We write this as: 5 > 3.

Given two numbers, one of them can either be "greater than", "smaller than", or "equal to" the other.

  • "Greater than" is denoted by the symbol ">" (e.g. 10 > 2)
  • "Smaller than" is denoted by the symbol "<" (e.g. 1 < 2)
  • "Equal to" is denoted by the symbol "=" (e.g. 2 = 2)

 

Tip: To remember which symbol is which, notice that, for ">" and "<", the bigger gap faces towards the bigger number. (Look at the examples 3 > 2 and 4 < 5 to see this: the bigger gap faces the bigger number, and the smaller gap faces the smaller number.)

 

How do we compare two numbers?

If the two numbers are written using the same digits in the same order, then they are equal.

Example: 1,243 = 1,243.

Otherwise, count how many digits each number has. The number with more digits is greater.

Example: Compare 989 and 1,256.

Answer: The number 989 has 3 digits, while the number 1,256 has 4 digits. The number with more digits is greater. So, 989 < 1,256.

But, if both numbers have the same number of digits, then the number with the largest digit on the left side is greater. If the leftmost digits are the same, compare the next digits to the right. Continue to do this, one digit at a time, until the digits are different.

Example: Compare 23,569 and 23,581.

Answer: Both numbers have 5 digits. So:

  • We start with the leftmost digits, "2" and "2", which are the same. So, we keep going right until the digits are not the same.
  • The next digits in both numbers are "3" and "3", which are also the same.
  • The next digits are "5" and "5", which are also the same.
  • The next digits are "6" and "8". They are different, and 6 < 8. Hence 23,569 < 23,581.

 

Summary: How to compare numbers

  • If the numbers look the same, then they are equal.

  • Otherwise, the number with more digits is larger.

  • If both numbers have the same number of digits, the number with the biggest leftmost digit is larger. If the leftmost digits are the same, compare the next digit to the right. Continue doing this one digit at a time until the digits are different.
